description.raw: {"nodeType":"document","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Holding those in power accountable while shifting resources toward investments that keep all communities safe","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}}]}

subPages.title: Plank 1: Protect communities with a new paradigm for public safety beyond policing

pageListingInfo.title: Create a new paradigm for public safety and shrink the footprint of policing

description.raw: {"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"We must ensure a new paradigm for public safety emphasizes non-carceral interventions and programs, not jails and prisons, to keep communities safe. ","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"document"}

detailPageTitle.pageHeadline: Protect communities with a new paradigm for public safety beyond policing

richText.raw: {"nodeType":"document","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"heading-3","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Public safety is served when all people feel safe and are safe in their communities. ","marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"But the nation’s current approach to public safety does the opposite: It endangers people and communities. The current system of policing and criminalization is one that has disproportionately targeted communities of color, beginning with slave patrols and continuing with modern-day policing practices, including brutal suppression of social justice, labor, and protest movements. Tactics like “stop and frisk,” police killings of Black people with impunity, police presence in schools that predominantly serve students of color, and disproportionate enforcement of drug laws against people of color all perpetuate this crisis.  ","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"To ensure all people can feel safe and be safe, we must end this racist and classist system of criminalization and build a system premised on actual safety and genuine accountability. Advancing a new paradigm for public safety requires rethinking the purpose and amount of resources that we give to punitive-, arrest-, and surveillance-focused activities. It also requires ending the discriminatory policies and practices that enable systemic abuses against Black, Brown, Native, low-income, and other communities. Because police departments receive so much funding and resources, less funding is available for the social supports and infrastructure that enable communities to be safe and thrive. Devoting more resources to providing these necessities — high-quality health services, well-resourced schools, good-paying jobs, affordable housing — is what keeps communities safe. ","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Real safety is located not in carceral institutions, but in rebalancing spending and meeting the needs of communities — especially Black, Brown, Native, and low-income communities — that have gone unmet for decades. It’s time to build new systems premised on real safety and accountability.","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Read our policy recommendations.","marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":" ","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}}]}

content.raw: {"nodeType":"document","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"heading-4","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Create new, non-carceral systems to manage crises — including crises related to mental health, substance use, and disability — and to address traffic enforcement without involving police. Mandate collection and public reporting of data surrounding all police-community interactions.","marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}}]}

{"nodeType":"document","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"heading-4","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Eliminate federal, state, and local laws that shield police officers from accountability, including qualified immunity and secrecy laws, and change policy and police practices to ensure accountability by creating a national “necessary” standard for when force can be used.","marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"data":{}}]},{"nodeType":"paragraph","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"","marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"data":{}}]}]}

{"nodeType":"document","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"heading-4","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Prohibit police from practices and tools that have a disparate impact on marginalized communities, including SWAT raids, predictive policing technologies, consent searches, and civil asset forfeiture.","marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}}]}

text.raw: {"nodeType":"document","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"paragraph","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Create a ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":"new framework for pretrial justice that maximizes pretrial liberty while ending racial and wealth-based discrimination. ","marks":[],"data":{}}]},{"nodeType":"paragraph","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"","marks":[],"data":{}}]}]}

promo2.title: Ensure an effective right to counsel

text.raw: {"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"States must fulfill their Sixth Amendment obligations and ensure a high-quality system of indigent defense. ","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"document"}

subPages.title: Plank 2: Enact common sense pretrial justice

description.raw: {"nodeType":"document","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"paragraph","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"We must build a new framework for pretrial justice that maximizes pretrial liberty while ending racial and wealth-based discrimination.","marks":[],"data":{}}]}]}

detailPageTitle.pageHeadline: Plank 2: Enact common sense pretrial justice

richText.raw: {"nodeType":"document","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"heading-3","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Every night, nearly half a million people sit in jail across America — and not because they’ve been convicted of any crime, but often because they can’t afford money bail. ","marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"data":{}}]},{"nodeType":"paragraph","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Our current system of incarcerating so many people while they’re legally innocent is racist, morally reprehensible, and unconstitutional. This profound injustice devastates families and communities. Being jailed before trial rips parents from their families. It increases people’s likelihood of conviction and of committing another crime. It causes people who are detained to lose their jobs and homes. It significantly increases the likelihood of future unemployment for those detained. It exposes people to infectious disease, mental illness, unsanitary conditions, sexual assault, and even death from suicide, violence, or medical inattention. Put simply, it robs billions of dollars from communities and the economy, and it causes immeasurable harm to those who can least afford it.","marks":[],"data":{}}]},{"nodeType":"paragraph","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"The time has come to completely overhaul the pretrial system and build a system that supports people and maximizes their pretrial liberty. Drastically reducing the number of people incarcerated pretrial means less money spent on jails and more money spent on local community-based efforts surrounding restorative justice, child care, housing, mental health and drug treatment, and other non-carceral programs. These sorts of investments will help keep communities safe while allowing people facing charges to show up for their court dates without the use of restrictive conditions. It is time to make policy changes that will ensure pretrial liberty — and human dignity — is protected for all people.","marks":[],"data":{}}]}]}

content.raw: {"nodeType":"document","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"heading-4","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Ensure that eligibility for pretrial detention is extremely limited, including only the most serious felony cases, and eliminate money as a way of unconstitutionally detaining people.","marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}}]}

{"nodeType":"document","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"heading-4","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Before imposing conditions or detention, require robust hearings — with counsel present — that start by presuming innocence and, accordingly, release. ","marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}}]}

{"nodeType":"document","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"heading-4","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Provide all people with pretrial supports, including text message reminders, child care, transportation assistance, and housing.","marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}}]}

promo1.title: Ensure an effective right to counsel

text.raw: {"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"States must fulfill their Sixth Amendment obligations and ensure a high-quality system of indigent defense. ","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"document"}

{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"States must stop criminalizing poverty and start using treatment, community investments, and social supports to address social problems.","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"document"}

subPages.title: Plank 3: Ensure an effective right to counsel

pageListingInfo.title: Ensure an effective right to counsel

description.raw: {"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"States must fulfill their Sixth Amendment obligations and ensure a high-quality system of indigent defense. ","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"document"}

detailPageTitle.pageHeadline: Plank 3: Ensure an effective right to counsel

richText.raw: {"nodeType":"document","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"heading-3","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"The Constitution requires that people charged with a crime be represented by a lawyer, even if they cannot afford one. The current reality falls woefully short of this guarantee. ","marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"data":{}}]},{"nodeType":"paragraph","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"More than 80 percent of people charged with felony offenses cannot afford a private lawyer and must rely on under-resourced systems of indigent defense, including overstretched public defenders with crushing caseloads, contract attorneys, or other forms of court-appointed counsel.","marks":[],"data":{}}]},{"nodeType":"paragraph","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"These indigent defense systems “exist in a state of crisis.” In some cases, people lack counsel entirely. In others, people are responsible for paying for counsel through fees they cannot afford. When counsel is provided, it is often in name only — lawyers who have too many cases, too little time, few resources for investigation and mitigation, and/or financial conflicts that make zealous advocacy impossible. These patchwork systems fail the most vulnerable in our society and contravene our constitutional obligation to provide a lawyer to everyone accused of a crime. They lead to more jail time and less justice. Instead, we must ensure prosecutions do not take place without a system of public defenders’ offices that have the resources and expertise to provide dedicated representation to anyone who is charged with a crime. Only then will the constitution’s guarantee of effective counsel be fully realized.","marks":[],"data":{}}]}]}

content.raw: {"nodeType":"document","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"heading-4","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"More than 80 percent of people charged with felony offenses cannot afford a private lawyer and must rely on under-resourced, over-burdened systems of indigent defense.","marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}}]}

{"nodeType":"document","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"heading-4","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Ensure that no one is prosecuted without provisions such that public defenders have manageable caseloads and resources to provide diligent, high-quality services for all clients at trial and on appeal.","marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}}]}

{"nodeType":"document","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"heading-4","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Support and promote efforts that ensure parity in funding, pay, attorney and investigator staffing, and resources for indigent defense vis-a-vis law enforcement and prosecution.","marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}}]}

text.raw: {"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"States must stop criminalizing poverty and start using treatment, community investments, and social supports to address social problems.","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"document"}

promo2.title: Ensure accountability and transparency in prosecution

text.raw: {"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"We must create a system that is fair, transparent, and accountable. ","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"document"}

description.raw: {"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"States must stop criminalizing poverty and start using treatment, community investments, and social supports to address social problems.","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"document"}

richText.raw: {"nodeType":"document","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"heading-3","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"The United States makes it a crime to be poor. ","marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"We jail people over unpaid debts. We keep people on probation because they cannot pay off their fines. We fine and jail persons experiencing homelessness for basic, life-sustaining activities like sleeping and sheltering themselves. We suspend and revoke driver’s licenses for unpaid fees and fines, making it impossible for nearly 7 million people to conduct their daily lives — to work, see the doctor, buy groceries, visit family, pick up and take care of children, and even to leave the house. And we deny voting rights to people who cannot pay criminal-legal debts.","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"This practice of criminalizing poverty disproportionately affects Black, Brown, LGBTQIA+, and low-income communities and turns jails into debtors’ prisons where poor people are incarcerated simply for being poor. Criminalizing poverty prevents families from thriving by exacerbating challenges low-income people already face. Incarceration lowers employment rates, destroys family relationships, triggers housing insecurity, and makes economic stability even more difficult to attain.","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Decriminalizing poverty is a necessary step toward building a world where we invest in low-income communities and ensure every community has the tools it needs to thrive. It’s time we take this step.","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Read our policy recommendations.","marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"data":{}}],"data":{}}]}

content.raw: {"nodeType":"document","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"heading-4","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Abolish fees and costs from the juvenile and adult criminal-legal processes.","marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}}]}

{"nodeType":"document","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"heading-4","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Require jurisdictions to offer non-carceral responses, such as free, need-based, and non-coercive social supports, for behaviors that are caused by poverty, mental health disabilities, trauma, or substance use.","marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}}]}

{"nodeType":"document","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"heading-4","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Prohibit incarceration, the extension of probation terms, voting restrictions, and driver’s license suspension for unpaid debts. ","marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}}]}

promo1.title: Ensure accountability and transparency in prosecution

text.raw: {"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"We must create a system that is fair, transparent, and accountable. ","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"document"}

{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"We must build a system where people returning from prison have access to non-punitive, community-based supports.","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"document"}

subPages.title: Plank 5: Ensure accountability and transparency in prosecution

pageListingInfo.title: Ensure accountability and transparency in prosecution

description.raw: {"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"We must create a system that is fair, transparent, and accountable.","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"document"}

detailPageTitle.pageHeadline: Plank 5: Ensure accountability and transparency in prosecution

richText.raw: {"nodeType":"document","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"heading-3","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Prosecutors have an extraordinary amount of power in the criminal-legal system, but they are subjected to almost no oversight. This combination of great power and little oversight creates a system that tramples on the rights of people charged with crimes. ","marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Given their broad discretion over which cases are charged, whether cases proceed to trial, and the sentences individuals receive, prosecutors exert enormous influence over who is subjected to the brutality of the criminal-legal system and for how long. Like the rest of the criminal-legal system, this discretion is infected with racial bias, which influences every step of the process. ","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Because of high rates of pretrial detention and mandatory minimum sentences, prosecutors have power to coerce plea agreements: People who are detained, facing financial hardship, and desperate to go home are more likely to plead guilty than take their case to trial, even if they’re legally innocent. Research shows that people detained before trial plead to more severe penalties than people charged with the same crimes but who aren’t detained. The vast majority of cases — 97 percent of federal cases and 94 percent of state cases — end in plea agreements.","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Even when prosecutors intentionally break the rules, such as by not fulfilling their constitutional mandate to produce exculpatory “Brady” evidence that favors those accused of a crime or impeaches a government witness, the court-created doctrine of “absolute immunity” protects prosecutors from facing liability.","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"We must build a system where prosecutors are accountable to the people and communities who are subject to the devastating toll of criminal prosecution. Our laws and policies must be changed to ensure sufficient transparency and accountability regarding prosecutorial decisions and prosecutorial misconduct. Above all, we must begin rebalancing our resources so that we invest in upfront, non-carceral services that address social problems wholly outside of the criminal-legal process. Only then will we be able to reduce the devastating effects of prosecutors with too much power and too little accountability.","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Read our policy recommendations.","marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"data":{}}],"data":{}}]}

content.raw: {"nodeType":"document","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"heading-4","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Abolish the “trial penalty” by passing legislation that codifies and strengthens judicial discretion and oversight in reviewing plea agreements.","marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}}]}

{"nodeType":"document","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"heading-4","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"End federal and state civil immunities for prosecutors.","marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}}]}

text.raw: {"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"We must build a system where people returning from prison have access to non-punitive, community-based supports.","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"document"}

promo2.title: Protect communities with a new paradigm for public safety beyond policing

text.raw: {"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"A new paradigm for public safety emphasizes non-carceral interventions and programs, not jails and prisons, to keep communities safe. ","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"document"}

description.raw: {"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"We must build a system where people returning from prison have access to non-punitive, community-based supports.","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"document"}

richText.raw: {"nodeType":"document","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"heading-3","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Effective policy requires a massive curtailment of probation and parole.","marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"data":{}}]},{"nodeType":"paragraph","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Proponents of probation argue it is designed as an alternative to incarceration, but much like parole, it is another form of carceral control that lands people back in jail and makes it almost impossible for them to build healthy, thriving lives. The reach of the criminal supervision system in this country is staggering: There are an estimated 4.5 million people on probation or parole at any given time in the United States. In other words, one out of every 53 adults in this country is on probation or parole.","marks":[],"data":{}}]},{"nodeType":"paragraph","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Besides severely restricting liberty with onerous requirements and the ever-present threat of re-incarceration, probation and parole require crippling fees levied on those most in need of a fresh start. People on parole are promised a \"second chance\", yet they are often forced to miss work and risk losing their jobs so they can make probation or parole appointments. Worse yet, minor violations, like missing a probation appointment — or the financial inability to pay fines or fees — can land people in prison all over again.","marks":[],"data":{}}]},{"nodeType":"paragraph","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"The time has come to dramatically rein in this system of mass supervision and free people from the control of the carceral state. We must build a system where those returning from prison have the non-punitive, community-based supports, affordable housing, mental health care, and employment they need to rebuild their lives and thrive.","marks":[],"data":{}}]}]}

content.raw: {"nodeType":"document","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"heading-4","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"The current system of probation and parole keeps people trapped in the system by the looming threat of reincarceration and heavily levied fines. Today, 4.5 million people or one out of every 53 adults in the United States is on probation or parole. ","marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}}]}

{"nodeType":"document","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"heading-4","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Ensure the primary purpose of any supervision is to provide community-based supports and services.","marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}}]}

promo1.title: Protect communities with a new paradigm for public safety beyond policing

text.raw: {"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"A new paradigm for public safety emphasizes non-carceral interventions and programs, not jails and prisons, to keep communities safe. ","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"document"}

{"nodeType":"document","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"paragraph","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Create a ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":"new framework for pretrial justice that maximizes pretrial liberty while ending racial and wealth-based discrimination. ","marks":[],"data":{}}]},{"nodeType":"paragraph","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"","marks":[],"data":{}}]}]}

rightText.raw: {"nodeType":"document","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"paragraph","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Explore our voting resources and learn how you can help transform the system when we vote for justice.\n","marks":[],"data":{}}]}]}
